newsitem.title: USA: U.S. airlines saw more calls ahead of excise tax.
newsitem.headline: U.S. airlines saw more calls ahead of excise tax.

text.p: Rushing to beat the 10 percent passenger excise tax, which returns at midnight, consumers flooded airlines reservation lines on Monday, carriers said.

"Our call volume was running ahead of normal for this time of year and the percentage of people making bookings on those calls is also higher than normal," said Tim Smith, a spokesman for AMR Corp's American Airlines.
The question remains whether or not airlines will tack the 10 percent excise tax onto existing fares, or absorb all or part of the tax themselves.
Carriers declined to comment on Monday on their plans, citing federal restrictions on "fare signaling" -- or commenting on future fare.
Some major carriers, such as Continental Airlines Inc , ran advertisements on Monday urging customers to purchase tickets before the excise tax returns at midnight.

"The major airlines are gearing up to add the 10 percent excise tax back to the current airfares," said Tom Parsons, author of Insider Travel Secrets and editor of Best Fares Discount Travel Magazine.
Major U.S. airlines recently raised fares by about 10 percent, citing higher costs due to tougher security measures and the pending excise tax.
Wall Street analysts question whether or not the airlines will be able to force consumers to pay both the higher fares and the excise tax.
"Twenty percent is a lot to put on consumers in a short time," Jeffrey Long, an analyst with J.P. Morgan Securities.
Airlines will add the tax starting at midnight, but may launch sales if bookings drop off radically, analysts said.
When the excise tax lapse on December 31, airlines initially passed the 10 percent savings on to consumers.
Then, carriers slowly began raising fares about six percent to eight percent, benefitting from funds that would normally go to the federal government.
